prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Circumbinary disk - CN 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to check the feasibility of using CN as a probe of the circumbinary disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is selected to detect both the continuum and a setup with molecular line transitions that are likely excellent probes of the circumstellar gas. This particular science goal is focused in the CN 2-1 line, which are expected to be an excellent probe of circumstellar gas (Guilletau et al. 2014). The spectral resolution for the CN windows, 0.19km/s, should be good enough to disentangle the kinematics (the expected velocity gradients are of few km/s: Jorgensen et al. 2009).

We want to resolve the circumbinary disk around VLA 1 and VLA 2 that are separated by ~0.6 arcsec. This suggests that the inner radius of the circumbinary disk is ~1.2 arcsec. SMA observations with a 3arcsec beam indicates that the outer radius is probably somewhat smaller than 2.0arcsec. This suggests a toroid-like structure with a width of less than 0.8 arcsec. To image well the circumbinary disk we propose an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec.

The 1.1mm dust continuum flux density of YLW 15 is 75 mJy (with a 3 beam: Jorgensen et al. 2009). This includes the contribution from the two circumstellar disks and the circumbinary disk. The contribution from the two circumstellar disks can be also estimated by extrapolating the dust emission detected at 7 mm by the VLA with an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec (Fig.2): 0.67 and 0.50 mJy/beam for VLA 1 and VLA 2, respectively. Assuming a spectral index of =2.0 (typical for circumstellar disks: Andrews & Williams 2005), the expected 1.1 mm fluxes for VLA 1 and VLA 2 disks are 27 and 20 mJy. Therefore, the circumbinary disc is expected to have about 28 mJy at 1.1mm and about 18mJy at 1.27mm (assuming a higher spectral index, 3, for the circumbinary material). Assuming that the emission arises from a uniform toroid of radius 1.4arcsec and a width of 0.4 arcsec, then the expected flux per beam at an angular resolution of 0.4arcs will be about 0.4 mJy/Beam, which will provide a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 for the circumbinary disk/toroid. Observations of the HCO+ 32 in YLW15 at 3arcsec shows a broad line (v ~10 km/s) with a peak intensity of 4 Jy/Beam with the SMA (Jorgensen et al. 2009). We expect the CN and C18O lines to be similar in flux, so the much better sensitivity of ALMA should detect easily these lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Circumbinary disk - C18O 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to check the feasibility of using C18O and other lines as a probe of the circumbinary disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is selected to detect both the continuum and a setup with molecular line transitions that are likely excellent probes of the circumstellar gas. This particular science goal is focused in the C18O 2-1 line, which are expected to be an excellent probe of circumstellar gas (e.g., Guilletau et al. 2014). The spectral resolution for the C18O windows, 0.19km/s, should be good enough to disentangle the kinematics (the expected velocity gradients are of few km/s: Jorgensen et al. 2009)

We want to resolve the circumbinary disk around VLA 1 and VLA 2 that are separated by ~0.6 arcsec. This suggests that the inner radius of the circumbinary disk is ~1.2 arcsec. SMA observations with a 3arcsec beam indicates that the outer radius is probably somewhat smaller than 2.0arcsec. This suggests a toroid-like structure with a width of less than 0.8 arcsec. To image well the circumbinary disk we propose an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec.

The 1.1mm dust continuum flux density of YLW 15 is 75 mJy (with a 3arcsec beam: Jorgensen et al. 2009). This includes the contribution from the two circumstellar disks and the circumbinary disk. The contribution from the two circumstellar disks can be also estimated by extrapolating the dust emission detected at 7 mm by the VLA with an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec (Fig.2): 0.67 and 0.50 mJy/beam for VLA 1 and VLA 2, respectively. Assuming a spectral index of =2.0 (typical for circumstellar disks: Andrews & Williams 2005), the expected 1.1 mm fluxes for VLA 1 and VLA 2 disks are 27 and 20 mJy. Therefore, the circumbinary disc is expected to have about 28 mJy at 1.1mm and about 18mJy at 1.27mm (assuming a higher spectral index, 3, for the circumbinary material). Assuming that the emission arises from a uniform toroid of radius 1.4arcsec and a width of 0.4 arcsec, then the expected flux per beam at an angular resolution of 0.4arcs will be about 0.4 mJy/Beam, which will provide a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 for the circumbinary disk/toroid. Observations of the HCO+ 32 in YLW15 at 3arcsec shows a broad line (v 10 km/s) with a peak intensity of 4 Jy/Beam with the SMA (Jorgensen et al. 2009). We expect the CN and C18O lines to be similar in flux, so the much better sensitivity of ALMA should detect easily these lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Circumstellar disk - CN 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to check the feasibility of using CN as a probe of the circumstellar disks

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is selected to detect both the continuum and a setup with molecular line transitions that are likely excellent probes of the circumstellar gas.

VLA 1 and VLA 2 are separated by 0.6 arcsec. The proposed angular resolution, 0.2arcsec, will allow to partially resolve the two circumstellar disk, which is enough to unveil properties of the disk (velocity gradients, inclination).

The contribution from the two circumstellar disks can be also estimated by extrapolating the dust emission detected at 7 mm by the VLA with an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec (Fig.2): 0.67 and 0.50 mJy/beam for VLA 1 and VLA 2, respectively. Assuming a spectral index of =2.0 (typical for circumstellar disks: Andrews & Williams 2005), the expected 1.27 mm fluxes for VLA 1 and VLA 2 disks are 20 and 15 mJy. Since we may only resolve partially the disk, the disk will be detected with a high signal-to-noise ratio. We note that the main uncertainty of this science goal as well the other two at 0.2arcsec angular resolution is whether will be able to detect molecular line emission. This is why we have choosen three different setup to include the most favorable lines (see Guilleteau et al. 2014). At 1mm and at 0.2arcsec the 1km/s rms is 2K. If the molecular gas is warm enough (T>10K) and a the column densities relatively high, then we should detect the molecular lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Circumstellar disks - C18O 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to check the feasibility of using C18O and other lines as a probe of the circumbinary disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is selected to detect both the continuum and a setup with moleculafr line transitions that are likely excellent probes of the circumstellar gas.

VLA 1 and VLA 2 are separated by 0.6 arcsec. The proposed angulr resolution, 0.2arcsec, will allow to partially resolve the two circumstellar disk, which is enough to unveil properties of the disk (velocity gradients, inclination)

The contribution from the two circumstellar disks can be also estimated by extrapolating the dust emission detected at 7 mm by the VLA with an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec (Fig.2): 0.67 and 0.50 mJy/beam for VLA 1 and VLA 2, respectively. Assuming a spectral index of =2.0 (typical for circumstellar disks: Andrews & Williams 2005), the expected 1.27 mm fluxes for VLA 1 and VLA 2 disks are 20 and 15 mJy. Since we may only resolve partially the disk, the disk will be detected with a high signal-to-noise ratio We note that the main uncertainty of this science goal as well the other two at 0.2arcsec angular resolution is whether will be able to detect molecular line emission. This is why we have choosen three different setup to include the most favorable lines (see Guilleteau et al. 2014). At 1mm and at 0.2arcsec the 1km/s rms is 2K. If the molecular gas is warm enough (T>10K) and a the column densities relatively high, then we should detect the molecular lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Circumstellar disks - C18O 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is to check the feasibility of using C18O 3-2 and other lines as a probe of the circumbinary disk

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is selected to detect both the continuum and a setup with molecular line transitions that are likely excellent probes of the circumstellar gas.

VLA 1 and VLA 2 are separated by 0.6 arcsec. The proposed angulr resolution, 0.2arcsec, will allow to partially resolve the two circumstellar disk, which is enough to unveil properties of the disk (velocity gradients, inclination)

The contribution from the two circumstellar disks can be also estimated by extrapolating the dust emission detected at 7 mm by the VLA with an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec (Fig.2): 0.67 and 0.50 mJy/beam for VLA 1 and VLA 2, respectively. Assuming a spectral index of =2.0 (typical for circumstellar disks: Andrews & Williams 2005), the expected 0.87 mm fluxes for VLA 1 and VLA 2 disks are 42 and 31 mJy. Since we may only resolve partially the disk, the disk will be detected with a high signal-to-noise ratio. We note that the main uncertainty of this science goal as well the other two at 0.2arcsec angular resolution is whether will be able to detect molecular line emission. This is why we have choosen three different setup to include the most favorable lines (see Guilleteau et al. 2014). At 1mm and at 0.2arcsec the 1km/s rms is 2K. If the molecular gas is warm enough (T>10K) and a the column densities relatively high, then we should detect the molecular lines. This setup contains the 13CO, which has a higher optical depth of than C18O so, at least we should detect this line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Among the major science impact that ALMA is already achieving is on the study of the disks. Here we propose to take a step further for a novel approach that only ALMA can achieve: a long term (20 years) monitoring of the orbital motions of a young binary stellar system. Such a monitoring will have a major impact on how a system (circumstellar and circumbinary disks) evolves with time over a significant fraction of the binary orbital period. As a first approach in this proposal we want to study the feasibility of such an ambitious project in a relatively short proposal. We want to elucidate which are the best molecular lines to trace the circumstellar disks as well as the circumbinary disk. To do so we request five different short science goals.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
